SENT.plain: In this study, we investigated the effect of vesicular zinc on ischemic neuronal injury
In cultured neurons, addition of a low concentration (under 100 microM) of zinc inhibited both glutamate-induced calcium influx and neuronal death
In contrast, a higher concentration (over 150 microM) of zinc decreased neuronal viability, although calcium influx was inhibited
These results indicate that zinc exhibits biphasic effects depending on its concentration
Furthermore, in cultured neurons, co-addition of glutamate and CaEDTA, which binds extra-cellular zinc, increased glutamate-induced calcium influx and aggravated the neurotoxicity of glutamate

In a rat transient middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) model, the infarction volume, which is related to the neurotoxicity of glutamate, increased rapidly on the intracerebral ventricular injection of CaEDTA 30 min prior to occlusion
These results suggest that zinc released from synaptic vesicles may provide a protective effect against ischemic neuronal injury
